which joined with the NAEB in soliciting the interest and leadership of the
American Council on Education and other organizations, the JCET was created,
with subsequent funds from the Fund for Adult Education (later the Ford Foun¬
dation), and this danger area was covered.
A second area of need was national understanding by the general pub¬
lic and educational leaders of the nation. This function was performed first
by the National Citizens Committee for Educational Television, with funds
from the FAE. It was later continued, and carried to completion, by the
National Educational Television and Radio Center.
A third area, and one of the most pivotal, was the program area. Recog¬
nizing its own inability to become all things to educational broadcasting, as
it had recognized this fact also in the instances mentioned above, the NAEB
Board urged the creation of a Center specifically for this purpose, and forwarded
to the FAE a resolution urging a grant for this purpose. The creation of NET
provided the organization to meet this need.
However, in meetings of representatives of all the above organizations
together with representatives of the ACE and other interested groups in Wash¬
ington in 1954 and 1955, it was agreed that these were not the only needs
which, if inadequately met, could mean the failure of ETV, or a repetition of
the fate of educational radio in earlier years *
